newsitem.title: INDIA: India rupee slips on month-end spurt in dlr demand.
newsitem.headline: India rupee slips on month-end spurt in dlr demand.

text.p: The Indian rupee closed at 35.64/65 per dollar on Monday, down from the opening rate of 35.60/61, with action shifting to the spot from the forward market, dealers said.
"The spot (rate) moved in jerks, all in one direction," said a dealer at a foreign bank. In the morning session, the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) bought dollars at 35.6250, dealers said.
In the afternoon session, a leading state-run bank began bidding for dollars, pushing the rupee to the day's low, the 35.6450/6550 level, dealers said.
After being stuck on 35.59/61 level for nearly a weak, the rupee moved in a wide range of 35.61/65 of Monday.
"It looks like the elusive month-end dollar demand has arrived,' said a dealer.
"SBI has said it will use its GDR dollars to match outflows," said a bank dealer, referring to funds raised by State Bank of India from the overseas equity market.
"The demand for dollars has been supressed -- it will assert itself," she said.
The forward dollar market was subdued on Monday. There was some import covering and the premia inched up, with April dollars quoted at 1.24/1.26 rupees towards the close.
The six month premia close around 7.07 percent annualised. It could fall further to around 6.5 percent, dealers said.
